_description: PDET context enrichment for DIM06 focusing on theory of change, causal pathways, logical frameworks, and assumptions in PDET municipalities

gate_1_scope.justification: DIM06 requires access to PDET theories of change, PATR causal frameworks, and pillar-specific intervention logics

gate_2_value_add.justification: Provides causal logic frameworks and assumption validation criteria critical for PDET intervention design

gate_3_capability.justification: Methods must extract causal claims, construct logic models, and identify implicit assumptions

all_pillars.justification: Theory of change is required for all PDET pillars; causal logic must connect pillar-specific interventions to outcomes and impacts

key_assumptions: Price volatility does not discourage production
No violent actors contest land claims
Job market exists for skilled labor

explicit_theory_of_change.justification: PDET addresses complex structural problems requiring explicit causal reasoning; implicit theories lead to implementation failures

common_pdet_assumptions: Land conflicts can be resolved legally
assumption_identification.justification: PDET operates in high-risk environments; false assumptions lead to failure; explicit assumption testing is critical

causal_mechanism_specification.definition: The specific process or pathway through which intervention causes change
examples: Land titling → perceived tenure security → willingness to invest → increased productivity
Peace pedagogy → changed attitudes → conflict resolution skills → reduced interpersonal violence
causal_mechanism_specification.justification: Understanding mechanisms enables adaptation when interventions fail; 'black box' theories prevent learning

evidence_base_for_causal_claims.justification: PDET municipalities cannot afford failed interventions based on untested theories; evidence requirement is fiduciary responsibility

context_specificity.justification: Theories that work elsewhere may fail in conflict-affected, institutionally weak, ethnically diverse PDET contexts

plausibility_check.justification: Implausible theories waste resources and undermine credibility; skeptical review is essential

gap_1_missing_theory.description: PDT lists activities, outcomes, impacts without explaining how activities cause outcomes
gap_1_missing_theory.impact: Implementation becomes ritual; no learning; failures not understood
gap_1_missing_theory.remediation: Require explicit if-then logic connecting each level of results chain

gap_2_implicit_assumptions.description: Causal logic rests on unstated assumptions (e.g., security, capacity, cooperation)
gap_2_implicit_assumptions.impact: Interventions fail when assumptions prove false; no contingency planning
gap_2_implicit_assumptions.remediation: Mandate assumption mapping with risk assessment

gap_3_linear_thinking.description: Theory assumes linear, predictable change ignoring feedback loops and complexity
gap_3_linear_thinking.impact: Interventions create unintended consequences; adaptation too slow
gap_3_linear_thinking.remediation: Require systems thinking; identify key feedback loops and tipping points

gap_4_borrowed_theories.description: Theories imported from other contexts without adaptation to PDET realities
gap_4_borrowed_theories.impact: Context mismatch leads to failure; 'best practices' fail in conflict settings
gap_4_borrowed_theories.remediation: Demand explicit context analysis and theory adaptation justification

gap_5_wishful_thinking.description: Theory requires heroic assumptions (e.g., armed actors will cooperate, institutions will transform rapidly)
gap_5_wishful_thinking.impact: Plans become aspirational; implementation faces reality shock
gap_5_wishful_thinking.remediation: Apply plausibility test; require evidence for optimistic assumptions
